conclusion: Determine the proportionality constant k in the Millikan oil-drop experiment by analyzing forces and motion of oil droplets.
Two spherical oil droplets A and B are located on the same vertical line between two plates with a voltage U applied.
Droplet A falls with a uniform velocity through a distance h1 in time t.
For droplet A, the net force is zero since it moves at constant velocity: mg = k m0^(1/3) vA.
Solving for vA gives vA = (m0^(2/3) g) / k.
Droplet B initially falls with the same velocity vA.
When voltage U is applied, B starts moving upwards with a uniform velocity vB through a distance h2 in time t.
For droplet B, the net force is zero: qE - mg = k m0^(1/3) vB.
The electric field E between the plates is E = U/d.
Solving for vB gives vB = (qU / (k m0^(1/3) d)) - (m0^(2/3) g / k).
Relate the distance h1 to vA: h1 = vA t = (m0^(2/3) g / k) t.
Relate the distance h2 to vB: h2 = vB t = ((qU / (k m0^(1/3) d)) - (m0^(2/3) g / k)) t.
From the equation for h1, solve for k: k = (m0^(2/3) g t) / h1.
From the equation for h2, express h2 in terms of k: h2 = (t / k) ((qU / m0^(1/3) d) - m0^(2/3) g).
Substitute k from the h1 equation into the h2 equation and rearrange: h2 = (h1 qU / (m0 g d)) - h1.
Rearrange to solve for k: k = (m0^(2/3) g t) / h1.
The proportionality constant k is given by k = (m0^(2/3) g t) / h1.
